Igor Correia de Almeida

  • Endereço para acessar este CV: http://lattes.cnpq.br/5889915171475592
  • Última atualização do currículo em 15/01/2016

Possui graduação em Farmácia pela Universidade Estadual da Paraíba(1981), mestrado em Ciências Biológicas (Biologia Molecular) pela Universidade Federal de São Paulo(1989), doutorado em Microbiologia e Imunologia pela Universidade Federal de São Paulo(1994) e pós-doutorado pela University Of Dundee(1998). Atualmente é Diretor da University of Texas at El Paso, Docente da University of Texas at El Paso, Professor da University of Texas at El Paso, Membro de corpo editorial da Parasitology International (Print), Membro de corpo editorial da Journal of Glycomics & Lipidomics, Membro de corpo editorial da Frontiers in Fungi and Their Interactions, Revisor de periódico da ACS Chemical Biology, Revisor de periódico da Acta Tropica, Revisor de periódico da BMC Microbiology (Online), Revisor de periódico da BMC Genomics, Revisor de periódico da Cellular Microbiology (Online), Revisor de periódico da Clinical and Vaccine Immunology, Revisor de periódico da Expert Review of Vaccines, Revisor de periódico da Experimental Parasitology, Revisor de periódico da Eukaryotic Cell, Revisor de periódico da Glycobiology, Revisor de periódico da Infection and Immunity (Print), Revisor de periódico da Journal of Parasitology, Revisor de periódico da Journal of Biology (Online), Revisor de periódico da Chemistry, Revisor de periódico da Journal of Mass Spectrometry (Print), Revisor de periódico da Journal of Proteome Research (Print), Revisor de periódico da Journal of Proteomics (Print), Revisor de periódico da Journal of Theoretical Biology, Revisor de periódico da Memórias do Instituto Oswaldo Cruz (Impresso), Revisor de periódico da Microbes and Infection, Revisor de periódico da Molecular and Biochemical Parasitology (Online), Revisor de periódico da Parasites & Vectors, Revisor de periódico da Parasitology (Cambridge. Online), Revisor de periódico da PEERJ, Revisor de periódico da Plos One, Revisor de periódico da PLoS Neglected Tropical Diseases (Online), Revisor de periódico da PLoS Pathogens (Online), Revisor de periódico da Proteomics, Revisor de periódico da Scientific Reports, Revisor de periódico da Small GTPases, Revisor de periódico da Vaccine (Guildford), Revisor de periódico da Vector Borne and Zoonotic Diseases (Larchmont, N.Y.), Membro de comitê assessor da National Institutes of Health, Membro de comitê assessor da National Institutes of Health, Membro de comitê assessor da National Institutes of Health, Membro de comitê assessor da National Institutes of Health, Membro de comitê assessor da National Institutes of Health, Membro de comitê assessor da National Institutes of Health, Membro de comitê assessor da National Institutes of Health, Membro de comitê assessor da National Institutes of Health e Membro de comitê assessor da National Institutes of Health. Tem experiência na área de Parasitologia, com ênfase em Protozoologia de Parasitos. Atuando principalmente nos seguintes temas:doenca de Chagas, Trypanosoma cruzi, glicoconjugados, Imunologia. Projetos de pesquisa
2014 - 2014
Exploration of the CD4 T-cell dependent humoral immune response to synthetic tetanus toxoid peptide-glycan conjugates as vaccines for Chagas disease
Descrição: To evaluate synthetic neoglycopeptides vaccine for Chagas disease in mice..
Situação: Concluído; Natureza: Pesquisa.

Integrantes: Igor Correia de Almeida - Coordenador / Michael Katja - Integrante.
2014 - Atual
Novel Vaccine for Chagas Disease: Efficacy Testing in Baboons
Descrição: Over the years, various groups have developed experimental vaccines, using mainly parasite lysates, or purified or recombinant proteins and peptides, and DNA, targeting almost exclusively protein antigens. Most, if not all, of these vaccines, however, have failed to provide sterile protection to animals challenged with different parasite strains. Although glycoconjugates (i.e., glycolipids and glycoproteins) are the major antigens on T. cruzi surface and contain highly immunogenic epitopes, they remain practically unexplored as vaccine targets. Patients with acute or chronic ChD, from diverse geographical locations in Latin America, have very high titers of trypanolytic anti-α-galactosyl antibodies (Ch anti-α-Gal Abs). These antibodies are protective and thought to be the major host immune mechanism controlling parasitemia at both acute and chronic stages of ChD. Ch anti-α-Gal Abs recognize highly immunogenic terminal, non-reducing α-Gal-containing epitopes or glycotopes abundantly expressed on major immunodominant glycoproteins (i.e., mucins and TS/gp85 glycoproteins) of the mammal-dwelling trypomastigote forms. Since these α-Gal epitopes are absent in human cells, we propose that an effective ChD vaccine could be obtained using these immunodominant B-cell epitopes. The experimental glycoconjugate or neoglycoprotein (NGP) vaccine, developed by Dr. Almeida (PI) and Dr. Katja Michael (Chemistry Dept., UTEP) (Co-PI), is based on a linear glycan (Galα1,3Galβ1,4GlcNAcα, or Galα3LNα or KM24) that exists naturally on the surface of T. cruzi, and does not exist in humans and Old World primates such as baboons. Therefore, this T. cruzi sugar is detected as a foreign substance and a powerful immune response is mounted against it in patients with ChD and in transgenic mice lacking this glycotope. After experimental immunization with KM24 coupled to a carrier protein (bovine serum albumin, BSA) (NGP KM24b), the immune system of the immunized animals are primed to recognize T. cruzi as foreign and to kill the parasites soon after they enter the blood stream, and before they can get into cells where they reproduce. The KM24b vaccine also induces strong CD4 (helper) T cell activation, as observed with other glycoconjugate vaccines, and production of cytokines essential for isotype switching (from IgM to IgG) and differentiation of activated B cells into memory B cells, thus leading to a long-term immunity. Animals vaccinated with KM24b show 100% protection against two consecutive lethal parasite challenges and 99.9% parasite load reduction in the heart, as measured by qRT-PCR. Finally, lytic anti-α-Gal Abs purified from KM24b-immunized mice, are able to partially protect mice against T. cruzi infection, indicating a potential therapeutic value of this NGP vaccine. In addition to the KM24h vaccine, Dr. Almeida and collaborator (Dr. Rosa A. Maldonado, UTEP) have developed a peptide vaccine (MASPpep), based on a highly abundant and immunogenic surface antigen (mucin-associated surface glycoprotein, MASP), secreted by infective T. cruzi mammal-dwelling trypomastigote forms. MASPpep differs from previous peptides used as experimental ChD vaccines, because it is a longer (20-mer) peptide containing multiple B cell and CD4 and CD8 T-cell epitopes. Thus, it elicits a strong anti-T. cruzi immune response in mice mediated by both B and T cells, resulting in a very good protection (~86%) against lethal parasite challenge. Mice vaccinated with MASPpep also show 97% reduction of parasite load in the heart. Our rationale to test MASPpep as vaccine candidate in baboons, alone or in combination with KM24h, is that together, these immunogens could strongly elicit both B and T cell-mediated immune responses, leading to a fully protective and, ideally, sterile vaccine against T. cruzi..
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.

Integrantes: Igor Correia de Almeida - Coordenador / Jonh Vanderberg - Integrante.
2014 - Atual
Synthetic neoglycopeptides as Chagas disease vaccines
Descrição: Chagas disease (ChD) is a devastating neglected tropical illness caused by the protozoan parasite Trypanosoma cruzi. It is estimated that 8-11 million people are chronically infected in Latin America, representing a substantial social and economic burden. Owing to the extensive global migration of asymptomatic, chronically infected individuals from endemic regions, ChD now affects thousands of people in nonendemic regions like North America and Europe. The two available drugs for ChD chemotherapy have limited efficacy in the chronic phase of the disease and are rather toxic. Moreover, there is no preventive or therapeutic vaccine for human ChD, despite numerous experimental efforts targeting almost entirely parasite proteins. Although glycoconjugates are the major surface molecules of the infective trypomastigote stages (from both insect vector and host cells), they remain completely unexplored as vaccine targets. Highly abundant T. cruzi trypomastigote surface glycoconjugates, such as glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI)-anchored mucin glycoproteins (tGPI-mucins), contain highly immunogenic terminal α-galactopyranosyl residues (α-Gal), which are not expressed in human cells. Accordingly, very high levels of trypanolytic, protective anti-α-Gal antibodies are observed in both acute and chronic stages of human ChD. We thus hypothesized that terminal α-Gal-containing epitopes could be highly effective vaccines for ChD. To test our hypothesis, we recently employed the α1,3-galactosyltransferase-knockout (α1,3GalT-KO) mouse model, which closely mimics the human humoral immune response against T. cruzi. As immunogen, we used the synthetic trisaccharide Galα1,3Galβ1,4GlcNAc (Galα3LN), which is one of the major O-glycans on tGPI-mucins, covalently linked to bovine serum albumin (BSA) as carrier protein. Galα3LN-BSA-immunized mice showed very high levels of protective anti-α-Gal antibodies, much lower parasitemia, and very low parasite levels in the heart, as compared to control BSA-immunized animals. Although not sterile, the protection induced by the Galα3LN-BSA vaccine was long lasting and dependent on CD4+ (helper) T cells. Based on these results, we hypothesize that the ideal vaccine for ChD should induce both humoral (B cell) and cellular (T cell) immune responses, since both lytic antibodies and T cells play a decisive role in controlling T. cruzi infection. Aiming at the generation of a ChD vaccine that provides sterile protection against T. cruzi mediated by both B and T cells, here we plan to synthesize a series of neoglycopeptides (NGPs) consisting of a well-characterized major histocompatibility complex class II (MHCII)-binding peptide, i.e., tetanus toxoid peptide (TTp) or ovalbumin peptide (OVAp), covalently linked to the immunodominant Galα3LN epitope. These synthetic NGPs will be employed for the immunization of α1,3GalT-KO mice and the B and T cell-mediated immune responses will be examined. To achieve these objectives, we propose three specific aims: Specific Aim 1: Chemical synthesis of α1,3-Gal-containing neoglycopeptides. Specific Aim 2: Vaccination of α1,3GalT-KO mice with synthetic α1,3-Gal-containing neoglycopeptides and evaluation of the protective B cell-mediated immune response. Specific Aim 3: Elucidation of T cell-dependent immune mechanisms by synthetic T. cruzi glycan epitopes. We anticipate that high levels of protective anti-α-Gal antibodies will be achieved following immunization with the synthetic NGPs. In addition, we will learn which NGP architecture(s) will be ideal for achieving long-term, sterile protection against T. cruzi, dependent on both B and helper T cells. We strongly believe that this project will establish the basis for development of the first synthetic glycoconjugate vaccine able to induce a long-term, sterile protection against T. cruzi..
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.

Integrantes: Igor Correia de Almeida - Coordenador / Michael Katja - Integrante.
2013 - Atual
Global Characterization of Protein Palmitoylation in Trypanosomes
Descrição: Dual acylation with myristate and palmitate is essential for targeting of some proteins to specific lipid domains, and is commonly observed on eukaryotic cell signalling molecules. While N-myristoylation is carried out by a single N-myristoyltransferase, S-palmitoylation is mediated by one of a number of palmitoyl acyltransferases (PAT), each having its own subcellular location and substrate specificity. Palmitoylation is an essential modification in all eukaryotes. One goal of our research is to define for the first time the subcellular locations and substrates of every PAT in a eukaryotic cell. We have chosen the single-celled eukaryote Trypanosoma brucei for our studies, an excellent model system for this kind of analysis given its complex cell structure and powerful genetic tools. Over half a billion people are at risk of infection with one of three neglected tropical pathogens: Trypanosoma brucei, the agent of African sleeping sickness (60 million), Trypanosoma cruzi, the agent of Chagas disease (100 million), and Leishmania species (350 million), the agents of cutaneous, visceral and mucocutaneous leishmaniasis. There is no vaccine to prevent and/or treat any of these neglected diseases. Moreover, the drugs available for treating these infections suffer from poor efficacy and high toxicity. There are species-specific PATs in all organisms. Therefore, PAT inhibition may be a potentially novel drug target for the treatment of these and other infections with eukaryotic pathogens. A complementary aspect of our work will be the identification of those palmitoylating enzymes that are necessary for parasite growth and survival during infection and are therefore potential drug targets. The Specific Aims of this project are: - To determine the palmitoyl acyltransferase-specific palmitoyl proteomes and map palmitoylation sites in T. brucei. - To localize each of the 12 T. brucei palmitoyl acyltransferases and selected substrates. - To investigate the palmitoyl acyltransferases as potential in vivo drug targets..
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.

Integrantes: Igor Correia de Almeida - Coordenador / David Engman - Integrante.
2010 - 2012

Descrição: To understand how T. cruzi shed vesicles secreted by the parasite are able to interact with host effector (receptor) molecules, leading to cell invasion and continuous escape from host immunity..
